FATE OF WORLD!
IN INDIVIDUAL'S

HANDS, HE SAYS
Dr. A. K. Chalmers, Noted
Pacifist Preacher, Addresses
Supper Club
INDIVIDUALISM HAS
PURPOSE, SAID
Calls Socialism A Denial Of
Essentially Necessary
Individualism
Each individual is responsible for
the world as it exists today, it was
asserted by Rev. Allan Knight
Chalmers at the third meeting of the
University Supper Club Tuesday
evening.
Man has throughout the ages had
an inferiority complex that leads
him to belittle himself in the presence of seemingly powerful forces
which dominate his life, he declared,
and today this complex gives expression in the question, "How can
I help -doing what I do? I am not
responsible." The psychologists of
today are largely responsible for
this line of thinking, according to
Dr. Chalmers, when they teach us
that it is heredity and environment
which makes individuals what they
are.
The spirit of the age is well expressed, continued the speaker, by
the mechanical man, Erich Robot,
recently created and which he had
a chance to interview. The robot,
as long as it is asked a fixed set of
questions, knows the answers, but
when Dr. Chalmers asked it what
would happen to the working men
which it would replace, it replied
in a flat, mechanical voice, "I don't
know."
It is only by expressing individualism, he averred, that this "r
don't know and care" attitude can
be overcome, for the fate qf the
world today is in the hands of each
individual. Pacifists are examples
of this "individualism with a difference." It requires fighting and
sticking powers uncommon in the
race, to stand up before an inflamed
mob as did · Jeremiah in the wartime play depicting the people askh1g. to be sent to war by their king.
Socialism is a denial of individualism and is often held today by
the man who "won't let anyone tell
him what to do," but is immediately
afterward seen in his car, waiting
for a red light to turn green, with
no traffic coming either way, said
Dr. Chalmers. It is these men who
still think freedom is, as it is so
ably expressed in Untermeyer's
Moses, "the refusal to obey."
The picture of Gandhi, walking
the streets of London forty years
ago, arrayed in "tall silk hat, spats
and a cane, corning home from a
dancing lesson," while today he
walks the same streets with the fate
of India in his hands, was used by
the Supper Club speaker as an illustration of a man who dared to be
different in a big way.
In his concluding remarks, he
stated that those who have to be
pushed won't transform the world,
but rather, those who have ability
to see for themselves. Galileo,
N ewtoa, and Wesley did not have
to be tapped on the back to be given
their message, but went out '1ooking for it.
In a luncheon gathering at 12 :30,
Dr. Chalmers discussed the subject
of beliefs and whether or not they
mattered. In his opinion, beliefs
make a man what he is. Further( Continued on page 2, column 3)

Boston, Dec. 10 (N. S. F. A.)The Roosevelt-for-President Club is

purpose of stimulating interest in
the coming election and aiding the
campaign of Governor Roosevelt,
of New York. It is planned to
send speakers to clubs and other
organizations in the vicinity of
Boston in the interest of his candi graduated from Harvard in 1904.

Four Seniors, One Junior
Publicly Iniatiated Into Engineering Honor Frat

L. G. SMITH PRINCIPAL
SPEAKER YESTERDAy
Hopkins Chapter Was Established On Campus
In 1919
Five Johns Hopkins University
undergraduates, four members of
the senior class and one member of
the junior class at Homewood, were
yesterday publicly initiated into the
Maryland Alpha chapter of Tau
Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity.
Those who were elected to the
organization were:
SENIOR CLASS:
DAVID MOORE BARRETT
HOWARD DONALD MACCLELLAN
LEROY STEGMAN
ROBERT EARLE WATTS
JUNIOR CLASS:
BRUCE ALFRED HERMAN

L. G. Smith, of the Consolidated
Gas and Electric Company, and
charter member of the Maryland
Alpha Chapter, was the principal
speaker. Mr. Smith told of several of his personal experiences as
an engineer, gave advice to the new
initiates, and spoke generally on the
Tau Beta Pi fraternity.
Initiates Named
The names of the initiates were
announced at the assembly, held in
Latrobe Hall yesterday morning,
by Dr. Alexander G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering at
the Hopkins. A summary of the
requirements for admission into
Tau Beta Pi was given by the
faculty member.
Good scholarship, leadership,
adaptability, character, activities,
personality, and fellowship are
among the attributes considered in
the selection of members to the
honorary fraternity, it was pointed
out. One-fourth of the enrollment
of the senior class is eligible for
membership, but only the most outstanding of the engineers in the
upper quarter of the class here are
chosen, it was said. One junior in
the upper eighth of his class is
named to the organization each fall.
Faculty Members In T. B. P.
Among the faculty members who
have been named to Tau Beta Pi,
Johns Hopkins chapter, are Drs.
John B. Whitehead, dean of the
School of Engineering and professor of electrical engineering; Wilbert J. Huff, professor of gas engineering; William B. Kouwenhoven, assistant dean of the engineering school and professor of
electrical engineering; J. C. W.
Frazer, B. N. Baker professor of
chemistry; John C. Hubbard, professor of physics; and John H.
Gregory, professor of civil and
·t

sam ary engmeenng.
Ronald B. Brook, president of the
active chapter at the Hopkins, presented a historical sketch of the
chapter and national fraternity.
Founded at Lehigh University in
1885, Tau Beta Pi was organized
on the Johns Hopkins campus in
1919. Dr. Christie, said Brook,
was instrumental in securing for
the University at Homewood a
chapter of the engineering organization. In the 60 chapters of the
fraternity, it was said, there are
approximately 15,000 members.

THE HONOR SYSTEM
In the minds of some of the
newer students in the University,
the "Honor System," when considered as to what it is and how it
works, may still be somewhat of a
problem. There are many who are
just fresh from schools where stringent rules governing examinations
were in force, and naturally when
they came to Hopkins and found
that there were no such rules, but
that we had an "IIonor System"they were somewhat at a loss as to
what it was all about.
There are two methods of regulating· examinations, open to every
school and university. The first
one, and by far the more often
used, is the method where those
taking the examination are put under the direct surveillance of some
teacher or instructor. The other
method that is used is the one that
is in vogue at the Hopkins; a man
is placed on his "honor" to do his
"own" work at all times. After
going over the examination papers
and making the necessary explanations, the professor or instructor
will retire to some secluded spot
and leave the students free to do as
they choose. This action must not
be misconstrued. His departure is
not a signal for open discussion of
the questions by small groups of
students, and the freedom given to
the students should not be misused
in this way. No license is given to
anyone to discuss any points of the
examination with any of his fellow
students. No so-called "huddle
systems" should be used. If the
questions are not self-explanatory
and doubt as to their meaning is
raised in the mind of a student, he
should seek an adequate explanation from the instructor and not
from the fellow sitting next to him.
During examination time, it may
seem strange to some to see students walking out of the examination rooms with the questions in
their hands and seeking out secluded spots where they can work
out the problems in privacy and
where peace and quiet reign. Under the existing system, every student is privileged to take his examination wherever he so chooses.
Vvhen a student turns in his paper
at the end of the period and signs
his name to the pledge, that signifies to the professor that all the
work contained between the blue
covers of the book is a result of the

Dr. J. R. Oliver Plans
Student Reception
Dr. John Rathbone Oliver, associate professor in the History of
Medicine at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School, is planning a reception for his class at the Welch
Medical Library. The purpose of
this visit is to introduce the students to some of the important men
at the Medical School.
Dr. Oliver expects to have Dr.
Vvilliam Welch, Professor Emeritus
of the History of Medicine and
Colonel Fielding Garrison, Librarian of the Welch Medical Library
at this gathering. Refreshments
will be served.
It is believed that his lectures on
the History of Medicine will be
Dr.
continued for two years.
Oliver wishes to explain the subject
111 great detail.

Plan Political Conventions
(From N. S. F. A.)

The University of Pennsylvania is planning to conduct
model Republican and Democratic
nominating conventions. The conventions will be composed of
delegations from all states which
have representatives in the student body. There will be a chairman for each delegation and the
procedure of a regular political
convention will be followed.

Joshua Logan, who takes an important role in "Death Takes a
Holiday," the current presentation
of the University Repertory Theatre at the Maryland Theatre, will
speak today before the clas"s in play
production, conducted by Dr. N.
Bryllion Fagin.
The university Repertory Theatre is an outgrowth of the little
theatre movement which has become
so popular in this country in recent
years. All the members are college
graduates.
The theme of "Death Takes a
Holiday" concerns the happenings
when Death, cu6ous to discover,
why he is feared, why mortals
cling to their mundane existence,

and what there is about this thing
called love, declares a moratorium
from his customary harvesting, and·
as Prince Sirki comes to earth as a
guest at a week-end house party.

"Spectator" Calls Grid Sport
"Murder" In Editorial Recently,
Says United Press
Death of 40 football players in
the past season today was labeled
"murder" in an editorial in the
Spectator, students' daily at Columbia University, which has been conducting a campaign against professionalism in college sports, according to the United Press.
"Forty deaths!'' the editorial exclaimed "1\ ice business for the Society of American Morticians.
"Football coaches and other phenomena of sports arranged things so
nicely for the mobs in the stands
that the players become human parasites," the editorial declared.
The Spectator does not expect
anything will be done about it, however, because football provides
"heavy-drinking alumnae an outlet
for their boyish emotions" and because it brings "nice graft for athletic association parasites, for publicity experts, for contest officials,
for ticket venders and even for occasional professors who don't mind
overlooking a little thick-headedness
in the classroom."

Users of Bell System service ask "Information" more than 1,000,000 questions every
day. Providing facilities for answering them
promptly, correctly, was one problem put up
to engineers of the Bell System.
So effective was their solution that this
prodigious task is now a matter of smooth
routine. They designed desks which enable

each operator to reach quickly the listings of
some 15, 500, 000 telephones. They developed
apparatus which automatically routes calls to
operators not busy- and should all . operators
be busy at once, it stores up calls and releases
them in the order received !
Efficient t.elephone service depends upon
working out interesting problems like t~is.

First Practice Held Yesterday
At Carlin's Rink;
Meeting Today

Officially recognized by the Athletic Board, the new Johns Hopkins
University ice hockey team will
swing into action for the first time
this season on Wednesday when
the Maryland Dents, represented by
students from the University of
Maryland Dental School here, are
to be met in "Iceland," the Carlin's
Park rink.
6 Teams In Squad
The Hopkins squad is represented
in a newly-organized Baltimore
league consisting of, in addition to
it and the Maryland Dents, the
Wal brook Hockey Club, the Greenspring Valley Hockey Club, the Mt.
Washington Hockey Club, and the
Forest Park Hockey Club.
Teams in this group are to play
three games each week, it was
learned, on Mondays, \i\Tednesdays,
and Fridays at Lhe looal rink.
Intercollegiate Rules
All members of the ice hockey
squads are to be players in amateur
·standing·. Intercollegiate rules are
-- to be employed, said Vernon Scheid,
graduate student in geology at
Homewood and one of the organizers of the Johns Hopkins team.
However, the only deviation from
the regular rules for intercollegiate
competition in this winter sport, it
was pointed out, is that five-man,
and not six-man, teams are to clash
in the Baltimore league. Each team
is to be supplied with ten uniforms
by the managers of the Carlin'
Park ice rink.
More than 22 students at Homewood turned out at the initial meeting for the organization of the Jay
squad, held Tuesday. Among those
who attended the meeting were Jim
Miller, Jack Turnbull, Bill Mettee,
Otts Phillips, Boots Ives, and David
Johnson. Turnbull, Phillips, and
Ives were varsity football men during the recently-concluded season.
Hopes To Be Made Minor Sport
It is hoped by those interested in
the Hopkins ice hockey team that
the Ath letic Board here will accord
it recognition as a minor sport on
the oampus in the winter of 1933.
,, During this season, said Scheid, it
is to be sponsored as an informal
sport and no award of letters is to
be made. Next season it is expected
that other Maryland colleges will
begin ice hockey and that a regular
collegiate league will be organized ..
Official practice for the Jays was
held yesterday from S :30 to 7 P. M.
The team was organized and a captain was elected at the initial practice at Carlin's. A coach is being
sought, it was learned.
Today at i2 :30, in Latrobe 120,
all undergraduates and graduates
interested in ice hockey will convene.

Fordham Gridders Not
To Choose Captain
'1932 Team W-ill
Have No Regular

Leader; To Do This In Respect
To Player Killed By Injury
The Fordham University 1932
football team plans to play without a captain .. This 'is to be done
as a mark of respect to Cornelius
Murphy, who died recently of injuries suffered in
game with
Bucknell, said a United Press story.
Murphy, the 01vy junior on the
1931 varsity, was considered a virtually certain choice for captain of
the 1932 team.

'Penny A Meal' Plan
Used By Barnard To
Aid Unemployed
(From N. S. F. A.)

New York, Dec. 10-For the past
two weeks Barnard College has
been running a drive for the unemployed of New York City. "A
Penny a Meal" plan has been worked out whereby students are urged
to give a penny for each meal they
eat. Boxes are placed at the exits
of the dining halls, cafeterias and
tea rooms for contributions. Up to
date, the scheme has worked well
and the fund has been growing by
more than fifteen dollars a day.

PLAN EVOLVED FOR
SELECTING U. S. TEAM
Strong Lacrosse Squad To
Take Field For Hopkins
This Spring
With Johns Hopkins being
ranked third among colleges in
this country, great interest has
been aroused concerning the
plans for the selection of the AllAmerican lacrosse team for the
Olympic Games. First and second places were given to St.
John's and Maryland, respectively.
Hopkins
represented
the
United States at the Olympics in
1928; since then St. John's has
\Von the national title.
New Plan Evolved
Next spring when their regular
seasons are finished, about SO college and club teams will be consic;lered, and from among them
eight of the best will play a round
robin series in cities in the East,
including Baltimore. Every game
played by each of these SO teams
will be judged in order to choose
the eight to play the elimination
series. The team winning this
series will then in June play an
all-star team taken from the
other outfits. This winner will
be the final selection.
Maryland Teams To Compete
Hopkffi.s, Maryland, St. John's,
and Mount Washington will be
leading competitors in Maryland,
a state which has ahvays featured
lacrosse.
Dr. Allen Voshell, of :H;opkins,
is on the committee planning
these Olympic Games.
With many veterans returning,
Hopkins will bid for high honors
with a strong twelve this spring.

Seniors Are To Wear
Blazers June Week
--Senior Class Dues W~re Fixed At
$25 At Meeting Held Wednesday;
Blazers To Cost $6.50
At the senior class meeting last
Tuesday, the suggestion that blazers
be worn by the graduating class
during June Week, was accepted.
The Hopkins seal and the class year
will be sewed upon the breast of
hese blazers. They will cost about
$6.SO.
The senior dues for this year
were fixed at $2S.OO at a meeting
held Wednesday. It has also been
announced that the pictures, which
have not been taken, will be made
this spring.

Coach \Valdo Hambleton, with
the aid of last year's veteran men,
has been supervising the formal
pre-season practices at the Knights
of Columbus pool. A vigorous and
extensive training season is planned
this year, and to fulfill this condition
n~emberships for the Knights of
Columbus have been procured for
the members of the squad.
Look For Winning Team
The aspect of a winning team,
when its candidates and veterans
are considered, has never been so
encouraging in years. A strong
representation of last years' SO and
100 yard and relay men, Capt.
Ernie Hanhart, Bud Frey, Paul
Doeller and G. Boyce constitute the
mainstay of this season's team.
Boyce, Hanhart, Sneeringer,
Cook, Balke, Holtzman and McGowan represent. the group working on the 440-yard events. It will
be remembered that Boyce holds
the Hopkins record for the 440yard free style swim. His present
condition and current performances
are satisfactory and warrant the expectation of an outstanding season.
Veterans Back
In the 200-yard breaststroke,
Sadtler and Stern, veteran men and
the latter a wearer of the major
"H" which he won for breaking the
Hopkins 200-yard breaststroke record, are back to strengthen the
team. Dorman, Bishop and Michel,
three freshmen of exceeding promise, have regularly attended the
practices in an attempt to secure a
place on the breaststroking squad.
Five freshmen with considerable
experiences and talent are out for
the free style short distance events.
The group comprises White, Levy,
Orth, Morfett and Carnara. The
former two were regulars on the
City College team. Sneeringer,
Muir, Balke, Hahn and McGowan
have also shown promis~ in the free
style speed events.
Davis, Levy, Holtzman, Sneer·
inger and Camara, versatile freshman natators, are out for the backstroke.
Diving Squad
Bill Reid, Bill Mettee,, McConnell, Senues and· Lesselbaum complete the squad as divers. Bill Reid,
who placed second to none last year
in the diving event, is expected to
emulate that notable performance.
The schedule is complete with the
exception of one open date for
which negotiations are being made.
This year's schedule represents one
of the most difficult and far reaching one in many years. Of the
nine meets thus far obtained three
are in Virginia, two are in New
York. one is in Delaware, and one
is in Pennsylvania.
The ninth and final meet is at
home with Lafayette.
Schedule Announced
The schedule is as follows:
Jan. 9 Sat.-Delaware (away).
Jan. 15 Fri.-Franklin and Mar·

The Johns Hopkins quint will
make its Eastern debut at Philadelphia next Tuesday evening
when the 1931-32 Jay five meets
a strong Temple University team
which trounced it last year to the
tune of 4S-26.
Line-Up Not Named
Although no definite announcement of the starting line-up ha6
as yet been made by Coach
George Darley, it is probable that
C. Kelly and Siegal will start as
forwards; Brooke or Camito at
center; and D. Kelly and Silverman at the guard posts.
Brooke and Camito have been
waging a merry battle for the Jay
tip-off position on the court, and
either is likely to be at center
against Temple at the opening
whistle.
40 Out For Squad
Approximately 40 basketball
candidates have been practising
for the past week at the Loyola
College gymnasium, Evergreen.
From this group the team to represent Hopkins on the court this
winter will be selected.
The Kelly brothers, Siegal, Silverman, and Brooke are veterans
from last year's quint, which was
defeated by Loyola, Army,
Georgeto~n, Western Maryland,
Maryland, Washington, Pennsylvania Military Academy.
Much Expected
Much can be expected from the
new edition of the court team.
Coach Darley, it is said, seems
pleased over his material. He expects Temple, with its 1930-31
varsity almost intact, to give the
Jays a battle next Tuesday.

Tudor-Stuart Club
Buys First Edition
One of the rare first editions of
Edmund Spenser's Prothalamion
has just been obtained by the Tudor
and Stuart Club of the Johns Hopkins University. This book was
published in 1S96. It has been estimated that it is worth $1,SOO. However, the club has bought it for
considerably less due to the present
business depression.
For eight years the society has
sought this book but it was not for
sale. This addition makes the club's
collection of Spenser's work one
of the most complete in this
country. Dr. French, Librarian of
the University, stated that this is a
real triumph for the Tudor and
Stuart Club.

Several Experienced Men Are
On Jay Wrestling
Team
The Johns Hopkins wrestling
team will inaugurate its second season as a varsity team by traveling
to Lexington, Virginia, tomorrow,
to engage the Washington and Lee
matmen. Although there has been
a squad · here for the past three
years, the present team is the second
to officially represent the university.
The varsity, which was selected
by Coach Gus Van Sant at the tryouts last Saturday, is composed of
the following men :
118-lb. class ............ P. Hartman
128-lb. class ................ L. Gamse
13S-lb. class .................. C. Savin
145-lb. class ................ D. Leury
lSS-lb. class ............. !. Ba::hman
16S-lb. class .............. A. Phillips
175-lb. class ............ M. Herman
Unlimited class ............ H. Sears
Of these ·men, Hartman, Leury,
and Sachs have had experience in
South
Atlantic
championship
matches. Savin is a former Polytechnic luminary, w)1ile Leury
starred at City.
In view of the wealth of material
that has responded to his call for
candidates, Coach Van Sant is looking forward to a successful season.

Major letters were awarded to
nineteen members of the past season's football squad at a banquet
held at the Hotel Emerson last
night. Minor letters were also
awarded.
Leading the list of recipients
were Oscar Helm and Adam Bialaskorski, both of whom have been
on the varsity for four campaigns.
Both also have held the position of
captain during their gridiron careers. Bialaskorski was captain last
year while Helm lead the Jays during the recent campaign.
Close behind came Bill Weitzel
and Dotig Turnbull with three majors. Others to receive majors were
Kelly, Phillips, Levy, Yearley, McClean, Reid, Beehler, Ives, Berger,
Bonke, Weeks, Russell, Wilfson,
and ·w atts (manager). Doty, Triplett, and Grochmal received minor
letters.
The banquet last night was informal. Among those to speak
were Henry Iddens, auditor, and
Coach Ray Van Orman, the latter
praising the unexpected good showing of this year's team. Several
members of the squad also delivered short speeches.

Dr. Cook Named Head
Of Professors' Group
Walter W. Cook, director of
the Institute of Law at Johns
Hopkjns University, was elected
president of the American Association of University Professors
to succeed W. B. Munro, professor of political science in the
California Institute of Tt!chnology.
Prof. Edgar G. Conklin, of
Princeton University, and Prof.
F. K. Richtmyer, of Cornell University, were named vice presidents. Harry W. Tyler, professor emeritus of Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, was reelected general secretary.

First Appearance Monday
The musicians made their initial
bow last Monday night when they
performed at the Pro-Cathedral,
University Parkway and St. Paul
Street. Among the many features
of the evening were the banjo duets
of Messrs. Reich and Gore, the
baritone solo of Mr. Proctor, and
the popular renditions of the Blue
Jay orchestra under the personal
direction of John L. Sullivan. A
dance was held immediately after
the concert.
Ronald Levy, president of the
Musical Club, has announced a
schedule for the remainder of the
season. It includes concerts at the
Maryland College for Women and
at the University Oub, both dates
for which are still pending. The
club will travel to Cumberland to
give its annual concert on February
5. A trip to Philadelphia is as yet
tentative.

HANDS, HE SAYS
Dr. A. K. Chalmers, Noted
Pacifist Preacher, Addresses
Supper Club
INDIVIDUALISM HAS
PURPOSE, SAID
Calls Socialism A Denial Of
Essentially Necessary
Individualism
Each individual is responsible for
the world as it exists today, it was
asserted by Rev. Allan Knight
Chalmers at the third meeting of the
University Supper Club Tuesday
evening.
Man has throughout the ages had
an inferiority complex that leads
him to belittle himself in the presence of seemingly powerful forces
which dominate his life, he declared,
and today this complex gives expression in the question, "How can
I help -doing what I do? I am not
responsible." The psychologists of
today are largely responsible for
this line of thinking, according to
Dr. Chalmers, when they teach us
that it is heredity and environment
which makes individuals what they
are.
The spirit of the age is well expressed, continued the speaker, by
the mechanical man, Erich Robot,
recently created and which he had
a chance to interview. The robot,
as long as it is asked a fixed set of
questions, knows the answers, but
when Dr. Chalmers asked it what
would happen to the working men
which it would replace, it replied
in a flat, mechanical voice, "I don't
know."
It is only by expressing individualism, he averred, that this "r
don't know and care" attitude can
be overcome, for the fate qf the
world today is in the hands of each
individual. Pacifists are examples
of this "individualism with a difference." It requires fighting and
sticking powers uncommon in the
race, to stand up before an inflamed
mob as did · Jeremiah in the wartime play depicting the people askh1g. to be sent to war by their king.
Socialism is a denial of individualism and is often held today by
the man who "won't let anyone tell
him what to do," but is immediately
afterward seen in his car, waiting
for a red light to turn green, with
no traffic coming either way, said
Dr. Chalmers. It is these men who
still think freedom is, as it is so
ably expressed in Untermeyer's
Moses, "the refusal to obey."
The picture of Gandhi, walking
the streets of London forty years
ago, arrayed in "tall silk hat, spats
and a cane, corning home from a
dancing lesson," while today he
walks the same streets with the fate
of India in his hands, was used by
the Supper Club speaker as an illustration of a man who dared to be
different in a big way.
In his concluding remarks, he
stated that those who have to be
pushed won't transform the world,
but rather, those who have ability
to see for themselves. Galileo,
N ewtoa, and Wesley did not have
to be tapped on the back to be given
their message, but went out '1ooking for it.
In a luncheon gathering at 12 :30,
Dr. Chalmers discussed the subject
of beliefs and whether or not they
mattered. In his opinion, beliefs
make a man what he is. Further( Continued on page 2, column 3)

Five Johns Hopkins University

Beta Pi, national honorary engineering fraternity.

organization were:

L. G. Smith, of the Consolidated
Gas and Electric Company, and
charter member of the Maryland
Alpha Chapter, was the principal
speaker. Mr. Smith told of several of his personal experiences as
an engineer, gave advice to the new
initiates, and spoke generally on the
Tau Beta Pi fraternity.
Initiates Named
The names of the initiates were
announced at the assembly, held in
Latrobe Hall yesterday morning,
by Dr. Alexander G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering at
the Hopkins. A summary of the
requirements for admission into
Tau Beta Pi was given by the
faculty member.
Good scholarship, leadership,
adaptability, character, activities,
personality, and fellowship are
among the attributes considered in
the selection of members to the
honorary fraternity, it was pointed
out. One-fourth of the enrollment
of the senior class is eligible for
membership, but only the most outstanding of the engineers in the
upper quarter of the class here are
chosen, it was said. One junior in
the upper eighth of his class is
named to the organization each fall.
Faculty Members In T. B. P.
Among the faculty members who
have been named to Tau Beta Pi,
Johns Hopkins chapter, are Drs.
John B. Whitehead, dean of the
School of Engineering and professor of electrical engineering; Wilbert J. Huff, professor of gas engineering; William B. Kouwenhoven, assistant dean of the engineering school and professor of
electrical engineering; J. C. W.
Frazer, B. N. Baker professor of
chemistry; John C. Hubbard, professor of physics; and John H.
Gregory, professor of civil and

was instrumental in securing for

fraternity, it was said, there are
approximately 15,000 members.

THE HONOR SYSTEM
In the minds of some of the
newer students in the University,
the "Honor System," when considered as to what it is and how it
works, may still be somewhat of a
problem. There are many who are
just fresh from schools where stringent rules governing examinations
were in force, and naturally when
they came to Hopkins and found
that there were no such rules, but
that we had an "IIonor System"they were somewhat at a loss as to
what it was all about.
There are two methods of regulating· examinations, open to every
school and university. The first
one, and by far the more often
used, is the method where those
taking the examination are put under the direct surveillance of some
teacher or instructor. The other
method that is used is the one that
is in vogue at the Hopkins; a man
is placed on his "honor" to do his
"own" work at all times. After
going over the examination papers
and making the necessary explanations, the professor or instructor
will retire to some secluded spot
and leave the students free to do as
they choose. This action must not
be misconstrued. His departure is
not a signal for open discussion of
the questions by small groups of
students, and the freedom given to
the students should not be misused
in this way. No license is given to
anyone to discuss any points of the
examination with any of his fellow
students. No so-called "huddle
systems" should be used. If the
questions are not self-explanatory
and doubt as to their meaning is
raised in the mind of a student, he
should seek an adequate explanation from the instructor and not
from the fellow sitting next to him.
During examination time, it may
seem strange to some to see students walking out of the examination rooms with the questions in
their hands and seeking out secluded spots where they can work
out the problems in privacy and
where peace and quiet reign. Under the existing system, every student is privileged to take his examination wherever he so chooses.
Vvhen a student turns in his paper
at the end of the period and signs
his name to the pledge, that signifies to the professor that all the
work contained between the blue
covers of the book is a result of the

Death of 40 football players in

"murder" in an editorial in the
Spectator, students' daily at Columbia University, which has been conducting a campaign against professionalism in college sports, according to the United Press.
"Forty deaths!'' the editorial exclaimed "1\ ice business for the Society of American Morticians.

nicely for the mobs in the stands
that the players become human parasites," the editorial declared.

anything will be done about it, however, because football provides
"heavy-drinking alumnae an outlet
for their boyish emotions" and because it brings "nice graft for athletic association parasites, for publicity experts, for contest officials,
for ticket venders and even for occasional professors who don't mind
overlooking a little thick-headedness
in the classroom."

First Practice Held Yesterday
At Carlin's Rink;
Meeting Today

Officially recognized by the Athletic Board, the new Johns Hopkins
University ice hockey team will
swing into action for the first time
this season on Wednesday when
the Maryland Dents, represented by
students from the University of
Maryland Dental School here, are
to be met in "Iceland," the Carlin's
Park rink.
6 Teams In Squad
The Hopkins squad is represented
in a newly-organized Baltimore
league consisting of, in addition to
it and the Maryland Dents, the
Wal brook Hockey Club, the Greenspring Valley Hockey Club, the Mt.
Washington Hockey Club, and the
Forest Park Hockey Club.
Teams in this group are to play
three games each week, it was
learned, on Mondays, \i\Tednesdays,
and Fridays at Lhe looal rink.
Intercollegiate Rules
All members of the ice hockey
squads are to be players in amateur
·standing·. Intercollegiate rules are
-- to be employed, said Vernon Scheid,
graduate student in geology at
Homewood and one of the organizers of the Johns Hopkins team.
However, the only deviation from
the regular rules for intercollegiate
competition in this winter sport, it
was pointed out, is that five-man,
and not six-man, teams are to clash
in the Baltimore league. Each team
is to be supplied with ten uniforms
by the managers of the Carlin'
Park ice rink.
More than 22 students at Homewood turned out at the initial meeting for the organization of the Jay
squad, held Tuesday. Among those
who attended the meeting were Jim
Miller, Jack Turnbull, Bill Mettee,
Otts Phillips, Boots Ives, and David
Johnson. Turnbull, Phillips, and
Ives were varsity football men during the recently-concluded season.
Hopes To Be Made Minor Sport
It is hoped by those interested in
the Hopkins ice hockey team that
the Ath letic Board here will accord
it recognition as a minor sport on
the oampus in the winter of 1933.
,, During this season, said Scheid, it
is to be sponsored as an informal
sport and no award of letters is to
be made. Next season it is expected
that other Maryland colleges will
begin ice hockey and that a regular
collegiate league will be organized ..
Official practice for the Jays was
held yesterday from S :30 to 7 P. M.
The team was organized and a captain was elected at the initial practice at Carlin's. A coach is being
sought, it was learned.
Today at i2 :30, in Latrobe 120,
all undergraduates and graduates
interested in ice hockey will convene.

Fordham Gridders Not
To Choose Captain
'1932 Team W-ill
Have No Regular

Leader; To Do This In Respect
To Player Killed By Injury
The Fordham University 1932
football team plans to play without a captain .. This 'is to be done
as a mark of respect to Cornelius
Murphy, who died recently of injuries suffered in
game with
Bucknell, said a United Press story.
Murphy, the 01vy junior on the
1931 varsity, was considered a virtually certain choice for captain of
the 1932 team.

'Penny A Meal' Plan
Used By Barnard To
Aid Unemployed
(From N. S. F. A.)

New York, Dec. 10-For the past
two weeks Barnard College has
been running a drive for the unemployed of New York City. "A
Penny a Meal" plan has been worked out whereby students are urged
to give a penny for each meal they
eat. Boxes are placed at the exits
of the dining halls, cafeterias and
tea rooms for contributions. Up to
date, the scheme has worked well
and the fund has been growing by
more than fifteen dollars a day.

PLAN EVOLVED FOR
SELECTING U. S. TEAM
Strong Lacrosse Squad To
Take Field For Hopkins
This Spring
With Johns Hopkins being
ranked third among colleges in
this country, great interest has
been aroused concerning the
plans for the selection of the AllAmerican lacrosse team for the
Olympic Games. First and second places were given to St.
John's and Maryland, respectively.
Hopkins
represented
the
United States at the Olympics in
1928; since then St. John's has
\Von the national title.
New Plan Evolved
Next spring when their regular
seasons are finished, about SO college and club teams will be consic;lered, and from among them
eight of the best will play a round
robin series in cities in the East,
including Baltimore. Every game
played by each of these SO teams
will be judged in order to choose
the eight to play the elimination
series. The team winning this
series will then in June play an
all-star team taken from the
other outfits. This winner will
be the final selection.
Maryland Teams To Compete
Hopkffi.s, Maryland, St. John's,
and Mount Washington will be
leading competitors in Maryland,
a state which has ahvays featured
lacrosse.
Dr. Allen Voshell, of :H;opkins,
is on the committee planning
these Olympic Games.
With many veterans returning,
Hopkins will bid for high honors
with a strong twelve this spring.

Seniors Are To Wear
Blazers June Week
--Senior Class Dues W~re Fixed At
$25 At Meeting Held Wednesday;
Blazers To Cost $6.50
At the senior class meeting last
Tuesday, the suggestion that blazers
be worn by the graduating class
during June Week, was accepted.
The Hopkins seal and the class year
will be sewed upon the breast of
hese blazers. They will cost about
$6.SO.
The senior dues for this year
were fixed at $2S.OO at a meeting
held Wednesday. It has also been
announced that the pictures, which
have not been taken, will be made
this spring.

Coach \Valdo Hambleton, with
the aid of last year's veteran men,
has been supervising the formal
pre-season practices at the Knights
of Columbus pool. A vigorous and
extensive training season is planned
this year, and to fulfill this condition
n~emberships for the Knights of
Columbus have been procured for
the members of the squad.
Look For Winning Team
The aspect of a winning team,
when its candidates and veterans
are considered, has never been so
encouraging in years. A strong
representation of last years' SO and
100 yard and relay men, Capt.
Ernie Hanhart, Bud Frey, Paul
Doeller and G. Boyce constitute the
mainstay of this season's team.
Boyce, Hanhart, Sneeringer,
Cook, Balke, Holtzman and McGowan represent. the group working on the 440-yard events. It will
be remembered that Boyce holds
the Hopkins record for the 440yard free style swim. His present
condition and current performances
are satisfactory and warrant the expectation of an outstanding season.
Veterans Back
In the 200-yard breaststroke,
Sadtler and Stern, veteran men and
the latter a wearer of the major
"H" which he won for breaking the
Hopkins 200-yard breaststroke record, are back to strengthen the
team. Dorman, Bishop and Michel,
three freshmen of exceeding promise, have regularly attended the
practices in an attempt to secure a
place on the breaststroking squad.
Five freshmen with considerable
experiences and talent are out for
the free style short distance events.
The group comprises White, Levy,
Orth, Morfett and Carnara. The
former two were regulars on the
City College team. Sneeringer,
Muir, Balke, Hahn and McGowan
have also shown promis~ in the free
style speed events.
Davis, Levy, Holtzman, Sneer·
inger and Camara, versatile freshman natators, are out for the backstroke.
Diving Squad
Bill Reid, Bill Mettee,, McConnell, Senues and· Lesselbaum complete the squad as divers. Bill Reid,
who placed second to none last year
in the diving event, is expected to
emulate that notable performance.
The schedule is complete with the
exception of one open date for
which negotiations are being made.
This year's schedule represents one
of the most difficult and far reaching one in many years. Of the
nine meets thus far obtained three
are in Virginia, two are in New
York. one is in Delaware, and one
is in Pennsylvania.
The ninth and final meet is at
home with Lafayette.
Schedule Announced
The schedule is as follows:
Jan. 9 Sat.-Delaware (away).
Jan. 15 Fri.-Franklin and Mar·

The Johns Hopkins quint will
make its Eastern debut at Philadelphia next Tuesday evening
when the 1931-32 Jay five meets
a strong Temple University team
which trounced it last year to the
tune of 4S-26.
Line-Up Not Named
Although no definite announcement of the starting line-up ha6
as yet been made by Coach
George Darley, it is probable that
C. Kelly and Siegal will start as
forwards; Brooke or Camito at
center; and D. Kelly and Silverman at the guard posts.
Brooke and Camito have been
waging a merry battle for the Jay
tip-off position on the court, and
either is likely to be at center
against Temple at the opening
whistle.
40 Out For Squad
Approximately 40 basketball
candidates have been practising
for the past week at the Loyola
College gymnasium, Evergreen.
From this group the team to represent Hopkins on the court this
winter will be selected.
The Kelly brothers, Siegal, Silverman, and Brooke are veterans
from last year's quint, which was
defeated by Loyola, Army,
Georgeto~n, Western Maryland,
Maryland, Washington, Pennsylvania Military Academy.
Much Expected
Much can be expected from the
new edition of the court team.
Coach Darley, it is said, seems
pleased over his material. He expects Temple, with its 1930-31
varsity almost intact, to give the
Jays a battle next Tuesday.

Tudor-Stuart Club
Buys First Edition
One of the rare first editions of
Edmund Spenser's Prothalamion
has just been obtained by the Tudor
and Stuart Club of the Johns Hopkins University. This book was
published in 1S96. It has been estimated that it is worth $1,SOO. However, the club has bought it for
considerably less due to the present
business depression.
For eight years the society has
sought this book but it was not for
sale. This addition makes the club's
collection of Spenser's work one
of the most complete in this
country. Dr. French, Librarian of
the University, stated that this is a
real triumph for the Tudor and
Stuart Club.

THREE OTHER MEETS

Several Experienced Men Are
On Jay Wrestling
Team
The Johns Hopkins wrestling
team will inaugurate its second season as a varsity team by traveling
to Lexington, Virginia, tomorrow,
to engage the Washington and Lee
matmen. Although there has been
a squad · here for the past three
years, the present team is the second
to officially represent the university.
The varsity, which was selected
by Coach Gus Van Sant at the tryouts last Saturday, is composed of
the following men :
118-lb. class ............ P. Hartman
128-lb. class ................ L. Gamse
13S-lb. class .................. C. Savin
145-lb. class ................ D. Leury
lSS-lb. class ............. !. Ba::hman
16S-lb. class .............. A. Phillips
175-lb. class ............ M. Herman
Unlimited class ............ H. Sears
Of these ·men, Hartman, Leury,
and Sachs have had experience in
South
Atlantic
championship
matches. Savin is a former Polytechnic luminary, w)1ile Leury
starred at City.
In view of the wealth of material
that has responded to his call for
candidates, Coach Van Sant is looking forward to a successful season.

Major letters were awarded to
nineteen members of the past season's football squad at a banquet
held at the Hotel Emerson last
night. Minor letters were also
awarded.
Leading the list of recipients
were Oscar Helm and Adam Bialaskorski, both of whom have been
on the varsity for four campaigns.
Both also have held the position of
captain during their gridiron careers. Bialaskorski was captain last
year while Helm lead the Jays during the recent campaign.
Close behind came Bill Weitzel
and Dotig Turnbull with three majors. Others to receive majors were
Kelly, Phillips, Levy, Yearley, McClean, Reid, Beehler, Ives, Berger,
Bonke, Weeks, Russell, Wilfson,
and ·w atts (manager). Doty, Triplett, and Grochmal received minor
letters.
The banquet last night was informal. Among those to speak
were Henry Iddens, auditor, and
Coach Ray Van Orman, the latter
praising the unexpected good showing of this year's team. Several
members of the squad also delivered short speeches.

Dr. Cook Named Head
Of Professors' Group
Walter W. Cook, director of
the Institute of Law at Johns
Hopkjns University, was elected
president of the American Association of University Professors
to succeed W. B. Munro, professor of political science in the
California Institute of Tt!chnology.
Prof. Edgar G. Conklin, of
Princeton University, and Prof.
F. K. Richtmyer, of Cornell University, were named vice presidents. Harry W. Tyler, professor emeritus of Massachusetts
Institute of Technology, was reelected general secretary.

First Appearance Monday
The musicians made their initial
bow last Monday night when they
performed at the Pro-Cathedral,
University Parkway and St. Paul
Street. Among the many features
of the evening were the banjo duets
of Messrs. Reich and Gore, the
baritone solo of Mr. Proctor, and
the popular renditions of the Blue
Jay orchestra under the personal
direction of John L. Sullivan. A
dance was held immediately after
the concert.
Ronald Levy, president of the
Musical Club, has announced a
schedule for the remainder of the
season. It includes concerts at the
Maryland College for Women and
at the University Oub, both dates
for which are still pending. The
club will travel to Cumberland to
give its annual concert on February
5. A trip to Philadelphia is as yet
tentative.
